title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Visual Arts (2010)
subject: Arts Education

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Visual Arts (2010)

5F35E10B28894221B1B502C6E34DAF05.description: Picks out elements that have contributed to formulating an appreciation that he/she could apply in subsequent projects (e.g. use of various sources of information, methods of reflexion using a journal and portfolio)

E6E4A12E85014143984EB29F72577B24.description: Describes aspects of his/her experience that are related to the procedures for appreciation and the strategies used (e.g. recognizing the knowledge acquired , focusing on the task, making active observations, adopting a positive attitude)

ED7BA8D47B1042B082E9AB6031E3C308.description: Describes aspects of his/her experience that are related to the procedure for appreciation, and more particularly to the strategies used (e.g. ability to reflect and make connections, to identify expressive elements, to make keen observations)

7C842DC5C2554698B6DEB0FFAC2E3A88.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in each of the programs

0A12EF207C5F4792B443CF942F4CAE40.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in the program

21D3964D6EE7419488ECEB472C25E960.description: Compares his/her point of view with the points of view of others (e.g. the symbolic meaning of the forms on a totem pole, the symbolic meaning of colours for Les Fauves, the symbolic meaning of lines in a media image)

63A085614B81491295BAFCE5C12E901D.description: Justifies his/her point of view based on information gathered from the image content, the meaning perceived, the appreciation criteria and the research accomplished

E79ED52E181246AC85FEE247369E6C73.description: Justifies his/her point of view based on observations and information gathered (e.g. gestures used by the artist, impact of the colours in a media image, characteristics of the artistic period to which the art work belongs)

062B932560914DEAB1F2CA394D2D1869.description: Uses subject-specific terminology in accordance with the prescribed terminology in each of the programs

52288254DE8A417BA4D499B6FDD27982.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in the program

C2AA1E8722A5456B9E3FA4CA307969BF.description: Makes connections between the elements observed, the meaning perceived and the information gathered regarding works from various artistic periods and movements, and the purpose of the symbolism of the image (e.g. high contrasts to create opposition, transparency to communicate ephemeral qualities, the use of patterns and motifs in Islamic art, the unusual and poetic universe of the surrealists, the shapes and colours of road signs)

27ED776569784CF1808020AE1E9E37CF.description: Makes connections between the elements observed, the meaning perceived and the information gathered regarding the characteristics of artistic periods and movements (e.g. use of contrasting colours to draw attention to a particular element, the colours on a coat of arms to show affiliation to a family)

96A4A538769E4B3CB5FD2AB77FD3D284.description: Makes connections between the elements observed, the meaning perceived and the information gathered regarding artistic periods and movements (e.g. information on the funeral rites practised in Ancient Egypt, such as the functions of sarcophagi and the symbolic meaning of their decorative ornaments; information on the influence of the Refus global on the procedures used by Québec artists of that time)

EF7330F5975949228A504C1177B713FD.description: Makes connections between the elements observed and the meaning perceived (e.g. colour contrasts that can produce dramatic effects, a scene from the everyday lives of explorers that can allow the viewer to understand their wretchedness)

AB36988C1A324D9996E16E21BBA34C92.description: Constructs his/her interpretation of the image

8965EB47883E4DD394F759F12D387441.description: Compares the visual evidence of gestures produced by technological methods and tools; and traditional materials and tools (e.g. in contemporary art, the use of texts and photocopies, the integration of sound elements, the recording of a live performance)

4399856EF24648C4AEFDA189B91511D4.description: Compares the visual evidence of gestures produced by various traditional and technological materials and tools (e.g. lines etched in clay Phoenician masks, notches made by chisel on a low relief wood carving)

0BEECB8CB20C42E2ABCCE1761EB58484.description: Differentiates ways to produce evidence of gestures from various materials and tools (e.g. the movements created with gouache and a dry or wet paintbrush, the refined gestures of Renaissance painters, the dynamic gestures of the American c. 19 abstract art movement)

4AF9F5F61BCA4C5BA1BD0529E169C96E.description: Picks out manners to create traces of gestures using various materials and tools (e.g. the expressive brushstrokes in Japanese works, paint applied using palette knives in certain works of the Automatists, the juxtaposition of random objects in Dadaist works)

9DFEDA25F8ED43A9B8CB0FA554153515.description: Picks out methods of representing space, including aerial perspective (e.g. a sharp and dark foreground against a blurred and pale background) and perspective with one or more vanishing points (e.g. representation of a street, a river or a path)

988067BB18394547967A1FABF65C72A7.description: Picks out methods of representing space and more particularly isometric perspective (e.g. representation of a volume using parallel lines)

23BE34CC1AAA4137B2A5FCA79DFD9DFB.description: Picks out methods of representing space, including perspective with overlapping and diminishing perspective (e.g. superimposition of forms to create overlapping perspective, variation of the size of elements in accordance with their distance)

F51254CDCD6C4D9F8EB43E7BAC577563.description: Compares the organization of elements in virtual, two- or three-dimensional space of the image being studied with the organization in other images (e.g. the positioning of elements in a painting, a video or an installation)

4045D51220BF47E2B14AD7CA6D04D797.description: Compares the organization of elements in the two- or three-dimensional space of the image being studied with the organization in other images (e.g. the quality of the lines, the superimposition of forms or volumes, the dynamic organization of space)

B35A30FCD6FA4BFCBD0019266714C164.description: Differentiates the methods of organize space in two- or three-dimensional space (e.g. place elements in symmetry to create balance in space; for sculpture, volumes are balanced vertically or horizontally)

EB13AF03D22F4D3A9C6729325B7C28C6.description: Picks out methods of organize elements in two- or three-dimensional space: enumeration, juxtaposition, repetition, alternation, superimposition, symmetry and asymmetry (e.g. alternation of elements to create rhythm, the dimensions of forms to highlight the elements)

2383F1438DE144E3BCE75E55EF3F596A.description: Compares the characteristics of the visual effects that result from elements of visual arts and multimedia (e.g. use of complementary colours to create contrast, fast forwarding through images to produce movement or express emotion, integration of video within a performance)

6620CCF5B03340B5AAEF7AF063B5AE68.description: Compares the visual and symbolic effects that result from the treatment of the elements of visual arts language and the choice of visual codes (e.g. choice of forms and colours that characterize the art of a people [Scottish tartan, Maori tatoos, arrow sashes])

FD2863C9FF2D4044ACEB613675542AFA.description: Compares the visual effects that result from the treatment of elements of visual arts language (e.g. colour shading, movement produced by curved lines, patterns and motifs created by alternating forms)

E0E070303CF24E54A84BA95F0B761020.description: Differentiates the visual effects that result from the treatment of elements of visual arts language (e.g. rhythm expressed through the repetition of forms; values produced by superimposing straight and oblique lines)

09260B20FE7D4A369E667875910CBBAA.description: Picks out the visual effects that result from the treatment of elements of visual arts language (e.g. the texture obtained through the repetition of short lines, the repetition of tasks to create values or shading)

143506F5A1844CA18C848DE0E9E2059D.description: Compares the elements of visual arts and multimedia language used in an image (e.g. the coloured pigment in paint and the colours in the transmitted light used in a virtual image)

0029CCDE7F6D4883B2826D0B012EDB76.description: Compares the elements of visual arts language used in an image (e.g. organization of space in in situ art, representation of space in Renaissance works)

B7DCECB0BAF74AE68DDC0E14B83611BB.description: Differentiates between the elements of visual arts language that make up the figurative and non-figurative forms (e.g. the vibrant colours and contrasts of Les Fauves, the clean lines and pure colours used by the Plasticiens)

4D8442E2E64C4DB19666461307B7AAA3.description: Picks out elements of visual arts language (e.g. primary colours, straight lines and purged forms in an abstract piece)

F0BDC8A0A2804184AE96B7151604B7A9.description: Places a spatiotemporal image in its production context, taking into account elements of content and information gathered from various sources (e.g. a poster announcing a consumer good, documentary photos for information purposes, a video to promote a product, a videoclip for entertainment purposes)

2AF7824506C44C2DAF46E7FB92984E1D.description: Places an image in its production context, taking into account elements of content and information gathered from various sources on different artistic periods and movements (e.g. prehistoric cave paintings, Ancient Egyptian frescos, old Québec architecture, the expressiveness of street art)

582967C94E814C51861F460CB52BC2EE.description: Makes connections between the elements represented, the historical and sociocultural aspects and the symbolic elements (e.g. characters in a silent film, an interactive video, a combination of still images projected onto an installation and looped sound tracks citing verses from a poem)

9CADE0BF738146E7A9594629957FA583.description: Makes connections between the elements represented, the historical and sociocultural aspects and the symbolic elements (e.g. scenes depicting portaging or hunting, sugar shacks and toboggan runs; form and colour of road signs)

2228B8EC948F45C1B9DF01A70AA8C191.description: Makes connections between the elements represented, the historical and sociocultural aspects present in the art work (e.g. ancient Greek sculpture of an athlete, children playing in an urban scene, a WWII-era sign calling on young people to enlist)

3883673EBD6848BBB0B428E92882EEE0.description: Picks out elements that are represented from various artistic movements and periods (e.g. portrait, self-portrait, landscape, still life, scenes)

A7F912C8ACF04CE3BAA8AEA2830129CC.description: Picks out elements that he/she could apply in a subsequent project, focusing on the relevance of his/her choices, the strategies used and the production context (e.g. knowledge of visual arts language and the organization and representation of space; time management; ways of taking advantage of unforeseen circumstances)

84B436DD32CB432FA9821751757FB1A9.description: Describes aspects of his/her experience related to the creative dynamic and the strategies used (e.g. reflecting on his/her experience, recognizing the knowledge acquired, setting goals for himself/herself)

6D28EA4D4EFD4BB6BB349CDDE0A07413.description: Describes aspects of his/her experience related to the creative dynamic and more particularly with the strategies used (e.g. searching for ideas during the opening phase, applying what was learned from experimentation during the productive action phase, ability to focus when producing the creation)

D19F344EFF4C4AAAA516E1C0AC462837.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in each of the programs

2EE6D37C9209491BBC2DA7DA49235254.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in the program

F8BEF3AA4C784F26A41E9A3C9FC97EA9.description: Shares his/her experience of media creation

C1DBB7CA4EAA43FC833D1EFB51FDF86D.description: Uses different methods of representing space (e.g. aerial perspective [atmospheric], perspective with one of more vanishing points) that are suited to the message and the target audience

237F9430442346E2A11425009F8E70CB.description: Uses different methods of representing space (e.g. perspective with overlapping, isometric perspective) that are suited to the message and the target audience

D7AD5FA20A684081BD805BDC76440EA1.description: Make use of the following methods of representing space (e.g. perspective with overlapping, diminishing perspective) that are suited to the message and the target audience

5DFA4803DCB94CF1B022C9A7625D1ECD.description: Uses personalized methods of spatiotemporal organization resulting from his/her explorations to increase the impact of the visual message on the target audience

19FE77CE84724A719B039DD1C8648076.description: Uses personalized methods for organizing space that results from his/her explorations in order to increase the impact of the visual message on the target audience

86B1F844D727477EAA941A1EC891F0AA.description: Uses some methods of organizing space (e.g. juxtaposition, repetition, balance, movement and rhythm) in order to highlight the visual message

194F9645209B4705A9D02C8CFF511E48.description: Uses a method of organizing space to increase the impact of the visual message on the target audience

CD1231E3E0BF4A34B9570648F50AAB95.description: Visual arts language (space) and spatiotemporal organization

44814BA43D204E4EA039399F1738C27C.description: Uses elements of multimedia language in a personal manner by taking into account previous explorations in order to clarify his/her message (e.g. pivoting a virtual object on all its sides to create 3D computer modelling, using high angle shots and low angle shots, introducing sound elements, zooming)

651E1FBB88F648C2A28986E247FD72D7.description: Uses elements of visual arts language in a personal manner by taking into account previous explorations in order to clarify his/her message (e.g. using a variety of lines to create texture, making use of values in colours and shades to create a monochrome)

66D0080418604271A081D32D4446C477.description: Integrates into his/her media creations various ways to make use of the elements of visual arts language that result from his/her explorations (e.g. creating a rhythm by alternating forms, lines or colours)

28C96E8FBDFA4A3790161E3302AA8171.description: Uses a variety of elements of visual arts language, including colours in transmitted light, to communicate his/her message

6AF76886846C42B08282B5D3FC8589F6.description: Chooses elements of multimedia language that will affect the target audience (e.g. wide angles, framing, lighting) and visual codes (e.g. forms, colours, pattern) i.

35A772C76F254B89BB90CE03AAA902D4.description: Chooses elements of visual arts language and visual codes (e.g. forms, colours,pattern) that will affect the target audience

3F6BDC972F814BCDBEB346B1D87CA764.description: Chooses elements of visual arts language that will engage the target audience (e.g. forms, colours, space)

337A6BCBB27B4AD580D9CBC2F334F4C1.description: Tries out different ways of using and combining elements of multimedia language and of visual arts language, if applicable, to create visual effects that will engage the target audience (e.g. using close-ups to highlight an element, tracking shots to show all angles of a situation)

0009329968BC4B28A158A57F2E982205.description: Tries out different ways to use and combine elements of visual arts language to create visual effects that will engage the target audience (e.g. using repetition and form alternation to represent a pattern, suggest volume by using values in colours and shades, creating a contrast by opposing warm and cool colours)

4CCCE1A149EF4C87897E6DB174CF72F3.description: Tries out different ways of using visual arts language to create visual engage that are more likely to engage the target audience (e.g. creating values by using various light and dark shades, creating rhythm through the repetition of forms) c.

22827F5B8C3F496A81344A4F29DC9DA8.description: Tries out ways of using elements of visual arts language (e.g. creating rhythm through the repetition of coloured stripes, converging straight lines to create the illusion of movement, adding contrast or transmitted light to a digital image, converging light colours[pigments] toward the centre of the image)

AFD1E118775D4FC9A1A94E03614E9850.description: Visual arts language and multimedia language

FBDA5A4B530648249AC8D6DFA27BB3F7.description: Manipulates traditional tools and tools that are specific to multimedia to conveyhis/her message (e.g. animating images recorded using a camcorder, projectingan advertisement using a multimedia projector)

E61C0935033149C99729279B076E64A8.description: Manipulates traditional or technological tools to convey his/her message(e.g. using an electronic pen and graphics tablet to draw freehand, digitizesobjects)

3803593CF82E4F26811474EE1CA74892.description: Manipulates tools to communicate his/her message (e.g. painting lines withgouache while varying the pressure on the paintbrush)

C7F056F1AE4E4BF4B576B763CF7BCA36.description: Handles tools while complying with safety rules (e.g. using knives to cut paper orcardboard into forms)

019EEF4080164722AE103AB6131FDB05.description: Handles the following tools: electronic pen and graphics tablet, drawing software,nib, nib holder, scissors, scanner, digital camera, image processing software

E81EF5DF27404DD5A91299B8FD22CB98.description: Uses transforming gestures in a personal manner to convey the message(e.g. producing specific effects when recording a video and doing the montage,projecting an image to create ambiance)

3F919134B1664664BF0BD9D9FF737959.description: Uses transforming gestures in a personal manner to communicate a message in concrete form (e.g. using various pressures to apply dry pastel, painting using varied or flat brushstrokes, creating or transforming a digital image)

3235AA1A23B24B00BD237731BDAAD613.description: Uses appropriate transforming gestures that are suited to the materials while highlighting the visual message (e.g. converging oblique lines to create the illusion of movement, applying coloured pigments with flat brushstrokes for characterizing forms, digitalizing some represented textures)

40265490862C47F8BC0A9293F2D38F8C.description: Uses transforming gestures that are suited to the materials to convey the visual message to be communicated to the target audience (e.g. promoting a clothing line on advertising posters, characterizing the surface of textiles to represent velvet, wool or jute)

7E157F9D8D66465ABE0FDB1CBB8E7A4C.description: Tries out different transforming gestures that are suited to the technological tools, the materials, the message being communicated to the target audience (e.g. creating and transforming a digital image, making video productions, animating an image )

B169420D42CE48EEB3E28B0DA7B3F8D6.description: Tries out different transforming gestures that are suited to traditional and technological tools; materials; the message being communicated and the target audience (e.g. superimposing lines to create values, digitizing images and objects)

BEFC7EDF63CA489DA61317454F9A42FC.description: Tries out different transforming gestures that are suited to the materials, the message being communicated and the target audience (e.g. making prints from engravings, using square drawing sticks for freehand drawing, cutting and gluing forms, applying coloured pigments)

9DE2D7065CA7431182E13E295DFB1AD5.description: Tries out different transforming gestures, including snipping, gluing shapes flat on a support, printing, folding, creasing, shaping, digitizing images, photographing, saving images and working on a digitized image

ACBADC28B8194C08B727553F03A74315.description: Uses transforming gestures and elements of media language

457B520AE67144128E873F70BB7BA98A.description: Makes some storyboards for his/her authentic and meaningful idea by taking into account the desired impact on the target audience (e.g. characters, various views, scenes)

2745CB854F9A4148831B97712C583677.description: Makes different sketches of his/her authentic and meaningful idea by using various observation and memorization strategies and by taking into account the desired impact on the target audience (e.g. observation of a cultural reference [object, event, character] to cover the message)

74D978DE4190428AABB0E6D4A960A190.description: Makes different sketches of his/her authentic and meaningful idea by using various observation and memorization strategies (e.g. observation of a subject’s characteristics, recollection of an action)

9FCC796A91AB473CA3F1C9EE65A69F96.description: Makes sketches of his/her idea (e.g. experimenting with forms, elements and sizes)

68F27AFE41EA452AA1F0511AB602A89C.description: Chooses an authentic and meaningful idea among those in his/her inventory which communicates to the target audience (e.g. acknowledge the interests of the target audience)

AA37200624884E5DA7C6CC1C921D8F20.description: Makes an inventory of authentic ideas based on research for the stimulus for his/her multimedia creation that take into account: the message to be communicated and information on the intended viewers; the content and characteristics of the media images; the role of the cultural references and the significance of the visual codes

4EC20DC7B77D48BAB2F17907FB919424.description: Uses ideas to create a media production

448C9C544B7C495AAE5B09EEDB69A890.description: Picks out elements that he/she could apply in a subsequent project, focusing on the relevance of his/her choices, the strategies used and the production context (e.g. knowledge of visual arts language and the organization and representation of space; time management; ways of taking advantage of unforeseen circumstances)

01E546498A764232981FEFA1A4D256A2.description: Describes aspects of his/her experience that are related to the creative dynamic and the strategies used (e.g. using the three phases of the creative dynamic, reflecting on his/her experience, recognizing the acquired knowledge , setting goals for himself/herself)

D84A286CF54F46C789A9B2FEF21287C4.description: Describes some aspects of his/her experience that are related to the creative dynamic and more particularly with the strategies used (e.g. searching for ideas during the opening phase, applying what was learned from experimentation during the productive action phase)

AF1095B0D3AB46519A1F0958F7C02D0F.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in each of the programs

998B1C1392B94BE49F75F686A9494146.description: Uses subject-specific vocabulary in accordance with the prescribed terminology in this program

93959B9D9701478DA60CAB0CBFEE01FA.description: Shares his/her experience of personal creation

0783D8D2D43A41189284AE29636F14B4.description: Uses different methods of representing space, including aerial perspective (atmospheric) and perspective with one or more vanishing points

17DF39CD00734AB39AD1B200EBDD8CCA.description: Uses different methods of representing space, including isometric perspective

80FE0DDF4EC14E638448031B197E5DDC.description: Makes use of the following methods of representing space: perspective with overlapping and perspective with vanishing point[diminishing perspective]

4556F15D89564803AE55748DA6A185F2.description: Uses personalized methods of spatiotemporal organization that result from previous explorations to convey his/her idea

8E55547E619F4209B46742FB4C983FFB.description: Uses personalized methods of organizing space that result from previous explorations to convey his/her idea

7AF4A7C349EC4669A44EA7F1DC5FD133.description: Uses methods for organizing space (e.g. juxtaposition, repetition, balance, movement and rhythm)

BC8DD89FC82A405C8AC574FB44697088.description: Uses the following ways of organizing space: enumeration, juxtaposition, superimposition, repetition, alternance, symmetry and asymmetry

C34243F125E14D6AAC6BF34F4345CB32.description: Visual arts language (space) and spatiotemporal organization

2BAC048C88C44D12B0426063D63C203F.description: Uses elements of multimedia language in a personal manner by taking into account previous explorations (e.g. pivoting a virtual object on all its sides to create 3D computer modelling, introducing sound elements, zooming )

4E0DCB072FEA42A085F507F9CB91EB8A.description: Uses elements of visual arts language in a personal manner by taking into account previous explorations (e.g. using a variety of lines to invent a texture, explore some values in colours and shades to create monochrome, using high angle and low angle shots)

B7674576C9FA44A887E1D74D68CC2A1E.description: Integrates into his/her creations ways of representing elements of visual arts language that result from his/her explorations (e.g. creating a rhythm by alternating forms, lines or colours)

EC22ABC0ECDB416CBF65DA1DCCF1B131.description: Uses a variety of elements of visual arts language, including colours in transmitted light

D430176346974B3FBC6B76C30160F21C.description: Tries out different ways of using and combining the elements of multimedia and visual arts language to create visual effects (e.g. use of close-ups to focus on an element, tracking shots to show all angles of a situation )

22CB6BF6633C4B4D9D5129CEFA6461AC.description: Tries out different ways and combining of the elements of visual arts language to create visual effects (e.g. creating a pattern through repetition and alternation of the forms, suggesting a three-dimensional space by proper use of values in colours and shades, creating contrast by opposing warm and cool colours)

A5B5FB3FEAE74E1FBA561BD4AAFDC4D0.description: Tries out different ways of using visual arts language to create visual effects (e.g. creating values by superimposing straight lines, varying the intensity of primary and secondary colours by adding white or black)

FF77BFD6B8774E0D9F583673849B58ED.description: Tries out different ways of using elements of visual arts language (e.g. suggesting a movement by convergence of straight lines, adding contrast or light to a digital image)

0E40ED2F32624BE083BD22C5C02470D6.description: Manipulates tools to support his/her creative idea (e.g. using software to animate photos, recording images through tracking using a camera on a tripod mounted on a wheeled platform, projecting an animated production on the wall using a multimedia projector)

AA3FA2945C774A5D8C01E00B12EE0655.description: Manipulates traditional and technological tools (e.g. using a gouge to cut into linoleum [linocut], hollowing out a clay form using a loop, wire and ribbon tool, embossing metal, cutting the leather to obtain a desired effect, tracing an outline with an electronic pen)

847ED3BB9F8849499F4811CD3249762F.description: Manipulates the tools to convey his/her creative idea (e.g. making lines in ink by holding the nib holder with a slight incline)

A539455D6EBD4073969CF7BE22BCFB3D.description: Handles tools including the roller and the knife while complying with safety rules (e.g. handling a knife to snip forms out of paper or cardboard)

5FCCAE0C9E62432C8FD25DA895541987.description: Handles the following tools: electronic pen and graphics tablet, drawing software, nib, nib holder, scissors, gouge, sculpting tool (wooden modeling tool, loop, wire and ribbon tool), scanner, digital camera, image processing software

A01E6BCCF3494576988A2F5EE1AB1F3F.description: Uses transforming gestures in a personal manner to support his/her idea (e.g. producing specific effects when recording a video and doing the montage[editing], subduing lighting to create an ambiance and achieve the desired effect)

C50ECE50E9C84CB8B9BA61B940AB47DA.description: Uses transforming gestures in a personal manner to support his/her idea (e.g. using various pressures to apply dry pastel, painting using varied or flat brushstrokes, pinching clay to create shapes, digitizing leaves while moving them on the scanner, embossing metal, cutting the leather to obtain a desired effect)

77138F8CC7C34A26BBBE749AE5F4E393.description: Uses some transforming gestures appropriate to the materials and that highlight his/her creative idea (e.g. engraving in malleable materials to obtain represented textures, making oblique lines to create the illusion of movement, applying pigments using varied brushstrokes to characterize forms, superimposing lines to create values)

8706C760EA34499D8EAEB8C63DA1AE9E.description: Uses transforming gestures on materials that support his/her creative idea (e.g. characterization of a dwelling by adding details such as bricks, stones, slopes, shingles)

620377D962CF437F87057D8C2CEC6F16.description: Tries out different transforming gestures that are suited for the materials (e.g. moving an object using digitalization, recording different points of view using a camcorder)

E86DC5B062ED4116BBFF0D521C190172.description: Tries out different transforming gestures, including technological tools and methods (e.g. assembling pieces of wood using screws, sculpting plaster using chisel or a rasp, drawing digital images using an electronic pen) and fine crafts (hammering metal, texturing leather with a punch, applying patina, glaze and engobe)

5E78A574FF4E4810A3A7EE7BB8A9B335.description: Tries out different transforming gestures that are suited for the materials, including modelling clay and gluing shapes in relief on a three-dimensional space (e.g. papier-mâché, various objects)

1B57B3B5F36843A8A74D938D03AD9ECA.description: Trys out different transforming gestures, including: snipping; gluing on shapes on a support, flat or in relief; printing; hollowing; folding; creasing; shaping; assembling and balancing volumes; digitizing images and objects; photographing; saving and working on a digital image

6C2D807538554C02BA0C1513A8901816.description: Uses transforming gestures and elements of visual arts language

5AABDFC46E2B44B097270B5502C57C6C.description: Makes storyboards (drawn and written) of the authentic and meaningful ideas he/she has retained (e.g. sketches for a series of characters in motion [characters, various views, scenes])

EC07FC5483894FDB89E6982C4D4F8737.description: Makes different sketches of his/her authentic and meaningful idea (e.g. sketches of his/her observations and the subject from various points of view)

1BD1DE7B2AF040118B1DA0F057F62E5E.description: Makes different sketches of his/her authentic and meaningful idea (e.g. sketches from his/her memory)

DC4014B5C9AD4FDD8B693B02C4DDC208.description: Makes sketches of his/her idea (e.g. experimenting with forms and elements using distinct, rapid strokes with light value)

46E791274F7F45A585F099F88DB5B4F6.description: Chooses an authentic and meaningful idea among those in his/her inventory (e.g. giving a personal response to the stimulus for creation without using stereotypes or making clichés)

DD506CA68FF54838B793F5E965EF3859.description: Makes an inventory of authentic ideas based on research for the stimulus for creation involving the content of works of art, cultural objects or media images, the styles of different artists, the characteristics of art movements, etc

D54BC661DAA742D69F9B8B0C8D2E5DD3.description: Uses ideas to create a personal work

E394C27171E24A0EB378010EE58A37CF.description: Situates cultural references in time and space (e.g. the Biosphere [the U.S. pavillion at Expo 67], the Refus global, from the paintbrush to the electronic pen, paint [tempera, oil, acrylic])

CED8D864744A4A0F838FDCF8E8E97842.description: Compares the functions of different cultural references (e.g. following the evolution of a useful object from its origins until today, the transformation of a celebration or ritual over the centuries)

DC45DE6E46E143B68A7C31B0B0BD2AF1.description: Associates some cultural references with aspects of his/her personal culture, with Québec culture and with other cultures (e.g. graffiti, tags, urban frescoes, architecture)

3A5329F93E434B69A1E0F61F331BB764.description: Describes the functions of personal images, media images and cultural objects (e.g. reflection of a people’s identify, participation in art revival, promotion of a product, celebration of an event or tackling a problem of a period)

025789B34F754BDF90C463A82228ED6D.description: Differentiates between personal images and media images (e.g. scene from rural settings or folklore , coats of arms, logos, product packaging)

395F77EE62414FC98004EF1B31574D11.description: Names some creators and some of their productions

F2F9C8AD76C44CF8BB3B4DEE7C49AA62.description: Compares multimedia productions (e.g. network art, robotic art, multimedia show) and various art works, including art works from Québec, that belong to different art movements and periods (e.g. silent films, photos on metal plates, flipbook, daguerreotype, zoetrope, performance)

BA752B52108549AA9DE49E338C224AD0.description: Compares art works, including art works from Québec, derived from different art movements and periods, including comptemporary and current art (e.g. hyperrealist, conceptual, installation, land art)

DCFC02C6375F4F97ABE6984D7C5EFDFA.description: Describes the characteristics of different periods and art movements (e.g. the varied brushstrokes of impressionists, the unusual compositions produced by the surrealists, the vibrant colours used by Les Fauves, the simplicity and mathematical rigour of the Plasticiens)

DC4B624F5D4D49789AA1387DFA8593BF.description: Associates works with different periods and associated artists with art movements (e.g. Renaissance, Baroque, expressionism, surrealism, futurism, Automatism, Group of Seven)

66BD38521DC5440397411239B1A52864.description: Places some periods and art movements in time and space (e.g. on a timeline: prehistory, antiquity, Middle Ages, Impressionism, Dadaism, Cubism)

7C690B7C2F554987A92DF56A0C3BBA20.description: Names some artistic periods (e.g. prehistory, Renaissance, contemporary)

98676C6F8F6641529474AB30ED17DA6D.description: Visual arts repertoire and cultural references

14A8D5BB8FC546348EC4AE43FFA4520B.description: Describes the functions of different types of perspective to produce an effect of distance or to suggest volume

782967B2C20643F98E990C79C49C21C5.description: Compares methods of representing three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional support (e.g. diminishing perspective, isometric perspective, perspective with one or more vanishing points, aerial perspective [atmospheric])

C93532C8BBF44D618B3C92CB8AD9CE1B.description: Describes methods of representing three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional support (e.g. diminishing perspective, isometric perspective, perspective with vanishing point)

73FF9DD5310E4F9A9FBE03129F61757F.description: Differentiates methods of representing three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional support (e.g. perspective with overlapping, diminishing perspective, isometric perspective )

269F1703F1E0450AA9C86AA1774FDF0E.description: Identifies two methods of representing three-dimensional space on a two-dimensional support: perspective with overlapping and diminishing perspective

2373AEFB05424453BBA2CBB5F957C827.description: Identifies various ways of organizing two-dimensional, three-dimensional, virtual and spatiotemporal space (e.g. point of view, image projection, installation and performance)

C0A3C5B67D01470EA47C5C1C47E4A278.description: Compares various ways of organizing elements in space, including balance, movement and rhythm

22061316007142179AED31EC9AF57BF3.description: Differentiates ways of organizing elements in two- and three-dimensional space (e.g. juxtaposition and superimposition, symmetry and asymmetry)

2C0AE25BAF454A65BF64B33F8C41FF8E.description: Visual arts language and multimedia language (space)

C6A4C2D21FE14AC9AE632008E67D19A9.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of the different types of volume (e.g. a sphere symbolizes entity and perfection; a cube represents stability)

06AE6991FFA34104BEB876E5064207DB.description: Compares various types of volume, including filled, hollow and empty volumes

8AA2A66093F3453898B301DB3B8CEF35.description: Differentiates between tangible volume and suggested volume

41F2DA684CF24BC1BCCF1B6BE036602B.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of different patterns (e.g. flower or nature in Roman architecture symbolize the harmony of the universe; patterns on Berber pottery symbolize the fertility of the land and of women)

6CCA574B1B2347639C5C820CA806DE21.description: Compares the functions of decorative patterns (e.g. to embellish or characterize a surface) and symbolic patterns (e.g. to express beliefs or specific meanings)

0F9FF3967B8D4E12AFE49CDDCF2666D6.description: Highlights the characteristics of different patterns (e.g. geometric, animal, floral or nature )

0884E9654A854F2196B8C34BD5502381.description: Identifies various patterns (e.g. flower, striped, checkered or polka-dot patterns)

9C5873E02D7045D5A7D844505B6980DB.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of different textures (e.g. roughness to symbolize discomfort)

7AABA6C626AF4DACAA42F2677B4250FC.description: Compares the functions of different textures (e.g. use of textures to distringuish a surface or to represent a specific material)

1C4A5C2C6E7642CBB24BD37C6A5135F7.description: Differentiates real textures and represented textures (e.g. use of drawn lines or dots to represent wood grain)

F8559E28CF6F4F17829EA5F7FD3116BA.description: Identifies a variety of textures (e.g. wood grain, textile fibres, fur)

A318DA3B70CA4390894FCFBCCA89B0FF.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of values (e.g. use of a light colour to paint an element to emphasize the subject)

AF6C5949F3B84A14935DE84C87AE047A.description: Compares the functions of values (e.g. for suggesting volume and perspective)

D7A080ED6B88479B9CBEB7684594BDC0.description: Differentiates values in tone, in colours and in shades

2CA7D6453FD040999D9D39627EAE1B81.description: Identifies values in tones, in colours and in shades

80DE60449CE1473CB7DA9B992A4DAE99.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of various colours of pigments and colours in transmitted light (e.g. in the Western world, black symbolizes mourning and red symbolizes passion and love)

A467D85DCDAC46D6A0CDD6BF679028BF.description: Compares the colours of pigments with the colours in transmitted light

30EE21D48D0A46A7B8A3A5DA29EF841A.description: Differentiates between the colours of pigments and the colours in transmitted light

6B9383F08F6846A988A00BF8C098CBC6.description: Describes the characteristics of certain colours in pigments

AE1B44030C9A4924BC0B1A1621AECF88.description: Identifies complementary and tertiary colours in pigments also

4775115254A14F42BDD4123C67BA0892.description: Identifies the colours in transmitted light, including intensity and contrast

FA060C9E466A4802B02CAB41ED6ECA36.description: Identifies in pigments: light and dark colours

7B38A2D732514EC2A6D675ABE1FAC7DD.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of various types of lines (e.g. a vertical line symbolizes strength, rigidity and stasis; a horizontal line symbolizes calmness, rest and tranquility; an oblique line represents movement, dynamism, ascension or falling)

FDB9BEEDDE3E4C98A2EB2D940005D31B.description: Compares the effects produced by different types of lines (e.g. use of straight and oblique lines enumerated or superimposed to create values)

8F9EFBA668384F5C9C318CC4E083CCA3.description: Describes the characteristics of various types of lines (e.g. a tangible line has a real thickness; an abstract line is created upon the meeting of two [coloured or uncoloured] surfaces)

ADE94D7176134530BA0030576D782980.description: Highlights the characteristics of various types of lines (e.g. thin, thick, continuous)

3DE6D3BE4F6846238447E33CB95772E0.description: Identifies various types of lines (e.g. drawn, painted, incised and tangible)

81DC38B79F8446EB9E386C46CE1FC2BE.description: Highlights the symbolic meaning of various forms (e.g. a circle symbolizes the absolute, perfection and infinity; a triangle symbolizes harmony and safety; a square symbolizes stability and the absence of tensions)

8ECDA0872ACF4CA8B52DCAEA7491D557.description: Describes the characteristics of figurative and non-figurative forms (e.g. precise, vague, detailed, simplified)

E4CBC89BC9A24D748303B4EEFB499994.description: Compares the potential of techniques (e.g. drawing with a nib versus animating an image using software)

893884AEC0D340CD9E099EF8B13093C1.description: Differentiates between techniques (e.g. assembling, shaping, modelling, animation, 3D computer modelling, photographing)

8CD1C6EDA8804F7F8848D6DFC3CCB7ED.description: Compares the potential of various techniques (e.g. for acrylic paint: producing the effect of transparency by adding water, or creating texture by adding polymer; and for textile productions: weaving fibres, producing embroideries, or felting wool)

34D5E42FC5C0431F92235C3B5CEB5F48.description: Compares technique variations (e.g. for assembling: gluing or assembling forms with wire; for ceramics: slab construction, wheel work and making coils)

082588AACD1641989E3489F23AA6459E.description: Differentiates between technique variations (e.g. when modelling clay, pinching and joining the clay, making forms by shaping and hollowing out the clay)

85288F52741D4E3989DAC848F0BE4067.description: Differentiates between techniques (e.g. drawing and painting, engraving and printing, shaping and modelling)

1030248C6D9C451E828A8911BEC6BE28.description: Identifies some techniques, including printing, assembling and shaping

C9FB2D1A5CBA4494AF628E22CC4B0E00.description: Compares traditional tools with multimedia tools (e.g. graphite pencil versus the drawing tool offered in an image processing software application)

0490C1C6EA194CEF985FAB3691D5BD8A.description: Compares the functions of traditional or technological tools with the tools used for fine crafts (e.g. pliers for cutting, turning and tightening; knives and cutters for glass, leather and wood)

2B7C10BB0C7C424FBED51CC6C6445E08.description: Compares traditional tools or technological tools with the tools used for fine crafts (e.g. paintbrush, brush, computer, drawing and image processing software, scanner, digital camera, gouge, chisel , pliers)

3F07657A2F094F9998A1E5FB18C3CC1C.description: Differentiates between the functions of various tools and their effects on the materials (e.g. a soft paintbrush to create fluid lines, a brush to create texture, a fine-nib to trace lines and a round-nib to make dots)

EEBE9C09291645F4B7723D4D8119C7FB.description: Differentiates between traditional tools (e.g. electronic pen, sculpting tool [wooden modeling tool; loop, wire and ribbon tool], gouge , scanner, nib, nib holder , graphics tablet)

A80A3A3148D94F83A2C060EA5C967601.description: Identifies the following tools: digital camera, electronic pen, sculpting tool (wooden modeling tool; loop, wire and ribbon tool), gouge , scanner , nib, nib holder , graphics tablet

52362274D47A443F9F17901F53547F28.description: Compares the properties of the materials (e.g. transparency of the light on an image depicted on digital or traditional support)

E03F6298682041B8BC006E354A11FA9A.description: Compares the properties of traditional materials (e.g. opacity of acrylic, fragility of polystyrene, resistance of the linoleum) and of materials that are suited for fine crafts (e.g. direction of the wood grain, durability of the resin, transparency of the glass, flexibility of the wire)

9B9A28F7D8B64948A6008F0DF9D9B325.description: Picks out the properties of traditional materials (e.g. opacity of printing ink, fluidity of India ink, transparency of coloured ink)

B7636B530E524391B15470200E19AFBE.description: Differentiates between traditional materials (e.g. graphite pen, drawing sticks [red chalk, bistre, black and white], clay, gouache)

ACC407B843924D508DD967C884C9271F.description: Identifies some materials (e.g. felt pen, gouache, oil pastel, India ink, coloured ink)

6E546A8E52784C6185FBA7F4504F2C4E.description: Compares the quality of the transforming gestures used on the materials (e.g. fastand slow, fluid and intermittent)

E9FB288A48B0430E90AEF64EE11BAF82.description: Compares the transforming gestures (e.g. video filmmaking, animating an image)

73F6E653D60D49B9BEE407E306979767.description: Compares the impact of transforming gestures on the materials

B4B86F4DB4F642FD99233733285945AD.description: Compares the properties of some transforming gestures that are associated withvarious techniques, including sculpting

BF32525A9C8747F9990E6FB54A39392C.description: Differentiates transforming gestures that are suited to various techniques (e.g. infreehand drawing, applying coloured pigments when painting)

C1E1BE93E0C444EAADF1CC57E7EDD9EB.description: Identifies some transforming gestures, including snipping, applying coloured pigments, assembling, notching, balancing, engraving, incising, shaping, photographing, pinching, digitizing, joining, freehand drawing, intaglio printing
